reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

The reading isn't the ば you learned with the kanji. It's a slightly longer ばあ, because you gotta be nice, you know? Also, the person you thought was a <vocabulary>granny</vocabulary> is actually a sheep. <reading>Baaaa</reading>! (ばあ).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.  First up, notice that <reading>いち</reading> changes to <reading>いっ</reading>. And since you haven't learned the on'yomi for the kanji <kanji>蹴</kanji> (kick) yet, here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you're planning <vocabulary>to flatly reject</vocabulary> someone, one <kanji>kick</kanji> is all you need. Before you do that, be absolutely sure to put your <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう) on first.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Okay, this is a great <vocabulary>value</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>price</vocabulary>. Wait, what is? <reading>A tie</reading> (あたい). Get a tie, and it will make you more professional which will help you to get a better job. Great value, right there, just for a tie.

When thinking about cars, an <reading>auto</reading>matic (おと) car is inferior to a manual car. Sure, manual is harder, but way more interesting to drive.

<reading>Awww</reading> (あわ), you're so pathetic it's cute! I will pity you. Reading also comes from 哀れ.

To spice up something you'd describe with words like <vocabulary>only</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>simply</vocabulary>, use "<reading>ta-da</reading> (ただ)" to spice it up. It's like magic! Now it isn't just a gift, it's a TA-DA surprise gift.

The reading for 唯 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, though there is also a shortened version which has ゆい shortened to ゆ. The reading for 一 is the one you learned with 統一, so you should be able to read it already!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading for 団 is an exceptional reading. It's the same as 内's reading so you can think about how a group of folding fans to make a big fan is just a bunch of fans inside of fans.

The reading for 扇 is also an exceptional reading. Imagine a <reading>wa</reading>lrus (わ) using the 内 fan.

The reading comes from 恨む, so if you know that no need to hold a grudge.

You just realized something so amazing that you can't believe it. That realization, wow! You were able <vocabulary>to realize</vocabulary> something so big that you <reading>sat</reading> (さと) down in disbelief. If you didn't you would have fallen on the ground.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Whenever you start <vocabulary>to panic</vocabulary> you can't help but blurt out, "<reading>A wha-</reading> (あわ)?" to everything people say and ask. For example, "Would you like a mint?" "A WHA?!" Yeah, you really do sound upset.
The reading comes from 憎む as well. Good times.
The reading comes from 憎む.
The reading comes from 憎む as well, so if you know this no need to show any hate towards this vocab.
The reading comes from 憩う, so if you know that you can rest easy.

The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic for you: 

You're most likely to need a <vocabulary>folding fan</vocabulary> in <reading>Auggie</reading> (おうぎ), AKA August, since that's usually when it's hottest in a lot of places. Just keep in mind that a folding fan = Auggie accessory, and hopefully the おうぎ reading will stick to you (just like the August humidity… unless you have an 扇 on hand.)

The reading for this word is different from both of the kanji readings you learned. This word sounds a lot like <reading>Jews</reading> (じゅず), so we'll have to go with that. Just imagine a Jewish rosary or prayer beads, with a Jewish person using it.

You look at the distance. You see something very <vocabulary>faint</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pale</vocabulary> out there. It's... it's... <reading>awwwa</reading> (あわ) a puppy! Awwwww! Aawwww!

If you get moist or moistened, then <reading>you're all</reading> (うるお) wet. It's just how it is.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 炊く.

The reading is 草 and 刈 put together into one. The か reading for 刈り comes from the kanji's reading.

You're wandering through the jungle exploring, when you come upon a deep pit. Since you're looking for treasure, you decide to go down into the pit to look for some. You take out your handy <reading>auto ro</reading>pe (おとろ), made of organic, environment friendly materials, and easily rappel down into the pit. Unfortunately, you get lost down there, and it takes you fifty years to get back to the pit you came in from. But your auto rope is gone! This is the last time you buy an organic rope, made <vocabulary>to decay</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to wither</vocabulary> away when left in the wild.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Of all the ideas that need <vocabulary>to be overturned</vocabulary>, it's the ones from the <reading>靴 guy</reading> (くつがえ). He thinks we should only wear shoes. Not shoes and nothing else, but shoes all over our entire bodies. Yikes, now that's an idea I'd like <vocabulary>to be retracted</vocabulary>, 靴 guy.

This has the same reading as 近い (ちかい). Just think about how when you're making a vow or oath, you become closer to the thing or person you're vowing to. You belong to them, in a way, which is why you become <reading>close</reading> (近い).
